story: Tesco, Asda, Waitrose, Sainsbury and MS all bought veg from firms that hired men and women brought into the UK by evil slave-masters.The huge gang collected around  ex-cons and alcoholics in Poland with the promise of good money when they got to England.But they were paid just p a day as the majority of their earnings from hard manual labour on farms, in factories and recycling centres were siphoned off.One worker, named Dariusz, was forced to load large crates of spring onions onto wooden pallets before they were taken to a warehouse and wrapped in Tesco and Asda branding, the Sunday Times reports.His slave-master promised him to chance to earn £-a-weekhe came with them to Britain – but instead he was forced to carry out backbreaking work and live in squalor.He said: “My le was controlled by these men.“I thought it was a good opportunity to leave my home country and earn some money. It would be a fresh start. But it was terrible.“When I was working at the farm, we would get up at am and I would be driven by a man to arrive for am. It was hard work. We were promised minimum wage — but I didn’t receive a penny.”Dariusz was kept in servitude in fear for his le after the gang told him he would be buried in a foresthe tried to escape.Led by the Polish Brzeninsky family the criminal mastermind gang pocketed £million.They housed their victims in horrendous conditions, and used them as what a judge described as commodities.As the bosses lived the high le - sporting lavish clothes, and driving luxury cars including a Bentley Continental - one worker was given coffee and a chicken as payment for redecorating a house.Another man had to wash in a canal because he had no other access to water, while one houses leaky toilet was plugged with an old duvet.Cops claim a number of victims worked at Sandields Farms, which is part of a larger firm that sell fresh produce like onions, celery and mushrooms to UK supermarkets.However, around  others were forced to make garden sheds and fences for a company called Forest Garden, based in Kidderminster.Forest Garden is a supplier for Homebase, Argos, Travis Perkins and Wickes.According to an investigation by the Times all of the supermarket and firms involved claim they knew nothing about the exploitation of the workers.One victim, describing horrible living conditions, said: I would say some homeless people here in the UK live better than I lived after I arrived over here.Victims were reduced to recycling used cigarette butts off the street, and going to soup kitchens and food banks to get enough to eat.After the end of two trials, it can now be reported how five men and three women, all originally from Poland, exploited their destitute victims for pure greed.They have all now been convicted of modern slavery offences and seven of their number, of money laundering.At their sentencing, Judge Stacey said their degradation of fellow human beings had been totally unacceptable, jailing the five for between  and four-and-a-half years.She said the defendants had subjected victims to a demi-le of misery and poverty, robbing them of their dignity and humanity without care or regard for the rights of the iniduals affected.There were a staggering , suspected victims in the UK from  countries in , including adults who had been used for organ harvesting and children that were forced into sexual exploitation.Up until recently, trafficked victims had just  days support after being recognised as a modern slavery victim before they were expected to leave the UK and were deported by the Home Office.During this short time, they were given accommodation, financial aid, medical treatment, counselling, a support worker, a translator and legal advice.Through our Stamp Out Slavery campaign, The Sun joined forces with Co-op to lobby the government to do away with the -day rule. And last week, the Home Office did just that. Now victims will continue to receive support as long as they need it.Jurors heard the accounts of more than  victims, but it is believed at least  more had been through the gangs hands, who had since either ed to their homeland, could not be traced, or were too scared to come forward.Victims would in some cases be frog-marched to cash points, to withdraw money and told they owed debts for transport costs, rent and food.The gang operation was smashed after victims were uncovered by anti-slavery charity Hope for Justice.The charity said  of the victims eventually made contact through its painstaking outreach efforts at two drop-in centres.The organisation was then able to flag the slavery rings existence to police.West Midlands Police then launched an investigation in February .At the end of the second case last month, a jury at Birmingham Crown Court convicted two men, -year-old Ignacy Brzezinski, from West Bromwich, and Wojciech Nowakowski, , of James Turner Street, Birmingham, of modern slavery offences.A third, Jan Sadowski, , from West Bromwich, admitted his part on the first day of trial.At a previous trial ending in February, leading conspirator Marek Chowanic, along with Ignacys cousin, Marek Brzezinski, recruitment consultant Julianna Chodakiewicz, Natalia Zmuda and Justyna Parczewska, the groups matriarch, were all convicted of their roles.Want to help  Here are some of the possible warning signs to look for, according to the Modern Slavery Helpline:Suspicious  You can call the Modern Slavery Helpline on   , or fill in an online report at: www.modernslaveryhelpline.org report

title: tanabata googe doodle 2019 festival
story: But what exactly is it about exactly  We bring you the lowdown on the festival of star festival celebrated across Japan...The Tanabata Google Doodle is a sketch showing small pieces of paper hung on bamboo spelling out Google.Each of the bamboo sticks are decorated with tiny yellow lights and part in the middle to show a dark blue sky which has a range of dferent seized stars dotted across it.The doodle is only showing on Googles home page in Japan.Tanabata was introduced by Empress Koken in  and it celebrates the meeting of deities Orhime and Hikoboshi who are represented by the stars Vega and Altair respectively.The legend says they are separated by the Milky Way and only get to meet once a year on the seventh day of the seventh lunar month.Japans celebration originates from the Chienese Qixi Festival. People in Japan celebrate the festival by writing wishes on small pieces of paper, known as tanzaku, and hanging them on bamboo.Some places will then place these on the river or set them alight in the days following the festival.The date for the festival changes every year due to the lunar calendar not matching up with the widespread Gregorian one.In , the search engine founders Larry and Sergey drew a stick figure behind the second o of Google as a message to that they were out of office at the Burning Man festival and with that, Google Doodles were born.The company decided that they should decorate the logo to mark cultural moments and it soon became clear that users really enjoyed the change to the Google homepage.In that same year, a turkey was added to Thanksgiving and two pumpkins appeared as the os for Halloween the following year.Now, there is a full team of doodlers, illustrators, graphic designers, animators and classically trained artists who help create what you see on those days.Among the Doodles published in past months were designs commemorating German scientist Robert Koch, Jan Ingenhouszand the th anniversary of kids coding languages being introduced.And the search giant celebrated the  Autumn Equinox , which marked the official ending of summer and the coming of autumn.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsBlack widow who earned £k as getaway driver turned down Reggie Krays marriage proposalEXCLUSIVE: Britains longest serving female gangster, Linda Calvey, reveals all in a new no-holds barred bookShareCommentsByScarlet Howes:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video sunday-mirror-exclusive-meet-black-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,consentCookies:DUMMY_COOKIE,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,groupmDisplayPrebidEnabled:true,displayPrebidEnabled:true,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFur coats filled her wardrobe and a string of lovers filled her heart… but it would all come crashing down for the Black Widow. Linda Calvey, who counts mobster Reggie Kray among her suitors, lived it up for years as an armed robber who learned the ropes from her first husband. She is said to have netted £million from crime – a conservative estimate, maybe, given her own boast that she netted £, a raid. Linda started out as a getaway driver, then became a gun-toting robber herself. Now , the woman who served  years for murdering one of her fellas is telling all in new book Black Widow.    Talking about her past as a robber, Linda told the Sunday Mirror: “The first time I was a driver. But then I would go in with a gun. “I was the silent one. I never used to speak during the robberies as I didn’t want them to know I was a woman, so I would just stand back and hold it. I was disguised with a balaclava and was meant to be the menacing one.” Linda, who served time with killers Rose West and Myra Hindley, added: “Planning would take months and the robbery would take minutes. “The police would say it’s ‘Black Widow’s gang’ and they were my gang. “They called me ‘lady boss’.” The Black Widow tag comes from her string of relationships. Most of the men who have fallen for her charms have wound up in prison or dead. Linda says: “I was a seductress. I lured men in with my web. And I always knew when I got one.” She was even proposed to by fellow killer Kray while in jail. They had met in a club before he was nicked in .    Years later, when Linda was also in jail, Kray got in touch. She explains: “He wrote to me and told me to be strong. Through my brother, who was locked up with him, we became pen pals. “He then started phoning me twice a week and I used to get bouquets from him. He sent me trainers once. “And then he asked me to marry him over the phone. I said it wasn’t good for either of us – really thinking it wouldn’t be good for me as I’d still be sitting there nowI was Mrs Kray. “I even made him a house in pottery class as his dream was to get home before he died. He was a romantic soul, and very quietly spoken.” Kray died in  aged , five years after mob twin Ronnie passed away. Linda’s lust for crime was fuelled when first husband Mickey Calvey was shot dead by the Flying Squad during an armed raid on a supermarket in .    He was nicknamed The Fonz after the character in TV’s Happy Days. Calvey’s gang plotted their raids in Linda’s kitchen as she made tea and sarnies. She maintains that she only got involved in the hard stuff after the death of Mickey, father of her children Melanie, , and Neil, . Linda says: “He was shot in the back and I became so bitter. I just wanted revenge. “When he was in his coffin I spoke to him and said, ‘I will do what you died doing and I will provide for our children’. And I decided I would become what I did become that day. “My love for him made me go crazy. On the outside I was me but on the inside I was a demon. I wanted to avenge my husband and in my mind that was doing armed robberies as he got killed doing one, however strange that sounds.    I was always attracted to money. The first time I robbed a bank I got addicted. My feet felt like they weren’t on the floor, it was a rush.” Linda – who told her kids not to follow her into a le of crime – says she committed around  robberies, adding: “I got around  grand a robbery – and we did loads. “It was very glamorous. I had a whole wardrobe of fur coats.” Linda hails from Stepney and became queen of the underworld in London’s East End. She hooked up with fellow crook Ronnie Cook. “Ron came and took my le over, I was in a bubble,” she recalls. But in  he was jailed for  years for robbery. Linda promised to wait for him and got a tattoo on her leg which read: “True Love Ron Cook.”    However, she started an affair with her partner-in-crime Brian Thorogood – who is also now dead – and ended up serving a three-year stint for involvement in a robbery herself. Linda says: “We got caught because Brian’s we had him followed by a private detective. They saw us on a robbery and reported it to the police. “The cops said I was so good they’d never have caught me and I thought, ‘Well, at least that’s something!’” It was only then, Linda says, that the gravity of her actions hit her. She adds: “First time I thought about anyone  was when I got arrested at my brother’s flat. “A policeman had a gun to my face and it was horric. It made me think, ‘Oh my God, that must be how people felt when we did it to them’.” By the end of the s, Cook was due for release and Linda was worried he might discover her infidelity. A jury later heard how Linda offered hitman Danny Reece £, to kill Cook. Reece was also in jail but on day release on the day of the murder.    Linda picked Cook up from Maidstone prison in  and drove him to her home in East London. Reece was lying in wait. As Cook walked in with the milk, Reece shot him – in the elbow. He was allegedly unable to finish the job. Linda grabbed the shotgun, shouted “kneel”, then blasted Cook in the head, the court was told. Linda was convicted of murder. Yet she maintains her innocence to this day. “I never killed him,” she says. “I was notorious and the police wanted me locked up. Brian hired Reece. “I think he wanted me back. Everyone said he was besotted with me.” Linda and Reece – both convicted of Cook’s murder in  – later married at Durham Prison, though the relationship eventually failed.    After Myra Hindley died, Linda briefly became England’s longest-serving female lag. Now she hopes her book will encourage someone to come forward to back her version of events. She says: “Why would I lie  I served my time and have nothing to prove. “I’m dferent from the woman I was  years ago. “I look back and sometimes think I don’t equate me with that person. “I regret everything after Mickey, but I’ve never felt sorry for myself.” One of Linda’s great sorrows is not being at the  wedding of daughter Melanie. “What should have been the happiest day of my le was awful. I was gutted. I couldn’t stop crying,” she says.    After a rollercoaster of crime and passion, Linda was freed in  and found love again with retired businessman George Ceaser, . But four years ago he was diagnosed with  tumours and died within a month. Despite her Black Widow nickname, Linda does not believe that she – or the many men in her le – were cursed. She says: “All the other men I met, other than George, were criminals. If Mickey hadn’t been an armed robber he wouldn’t have got shot. And then I wouldn’t have met Ron and he wouldn’t have died. Maybe bad judgment but certainly not a curse.” And of the future  “I’d never say never when it comes to love,” she says. “But is anyone brave enough  With my past I can hardly join a dating website. What would I put in the bio ” aposI cut Myra Hindleyaposs hair in jail - and she was bitter until her dying dayapos    Jailed Linda served alongside Moors Murderer Myra Hindley three times – and even did her hair. In her book, ex-gangster Linda says Hindley – convicted with Ian Brady over the deaths of five Lancashire children in the s – remained bitter and twisted until her dying day. Bleating Hindley blamed her actions on Brady and even insulted the mother of victim Lesley Anne Downey, . Linda says: “She was very bitter and believed she shouldn’t be in prison. She was especially bitter towards Lesley Anne Downey’s mum and called her ‘that bloody woman’. “She had a locked briefcase under her bed and told me it was her personal papers. I found it when a spider crawled from under her bed and I asked her to kill it. But she wouldn’t. She told me to kill it as I’m the Black Widow.” Linda and Hindley, who died in  aged , rubbed shoulders at Cookham Wood jail, Kent, at Durham Prison and finally at Highpoint, Suffolk – where she became her hairdresser. Trained crimper Linda goes on: “She was fussy about her hair as that was the only control she had left. She’d send me Christmas cards and phoned her mother to say she had a lovely friend. “I would think ‘I’m not your friend’ but I would talk to her mum as I felt sorry for her having a daughter like that.” Black Widow, £. from Mirror Books is out Thursday

story: NewsGrief-stricken mum hasnt seen her daughter since she was abducted seven years agoMalgorzata Symanowiczs husband Maher Belaid took their baby daughter Talia to Libya hours after a family shopping trip in CardfShareCommentsByRuth MosalskiBradley JollyOnline journalist:,  JUL NewsMalgorzata Szymanowicz, , has spoken about how her baby daughter was kidnapped by her estranged husband "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum has spoken of her grief at not seeing her daughter in the flesh in seven years - ever since she was abducted by her then-husband and taken to Libya.Malgorzata Symanowicz, known as Gosia by pals, yearns to be reunited with little Talia. Her daughter was just -weeks-old when her cruel dad Maher Belaid snatched her in a Mothercare, during a family shopping trip in Cardf. He flew to the city of Tripoli, Libya, where she remains.Wales Online reports Belaid was jailed for six-and-a-half years for the kidnap in .But Polish-born Gosia, now , is begging for help. I hope somebody can do something, she said.    How can I live  Every day everything I do is for Talia. Sometimes I don’t feel okay and I have bad days but it’s important I get up and do something. But I find it hard to trust anyone. He said he would never take Talia and that happened. I now know he planned everything. He did it behind my back. He told he didn’t but how can you take a child from the country without any plans  You have to have everything ready.    Gosia, from Roath, Cardf, added: I havenapost seen my daughter since she was three months old when she was abducted to a foreign country by my husband. She is now seven years old. Not a day goes by when I donapost think about her and worry about her safety in such a dangerous and unstable country. My heart is broken without her, I have missed so much of her childhood and I ache to be reunited and hold her in my arms. I cannot give up until I find her but I cannot do this without help from the government. The mum had a phone call earlier this year askingshe knew where her ex was. A warrant was issued for Belaidaposs arrest and when he is found he could be ed to prison for breaching the terms of his release on licence, according to barrister Mark Jarman, who represented Ms Szymanowicz in the High Court.  Gosia, who first met Belaid when the pair were working in a Dominoaposs, recalled the day he snatched their child - November , . He said we would go shopping to buy things for Talia and presents for my mum back in Poland, she said. He said he would go with Talia and go for a coffee with his friend and said I could do the shopping by myself. I kept calling and checking they were okay and he said she was. Around pm I said I was going home and askedhe wanted me to pick him up. But he said ‘Don’t worry’ and his friend would drop him home.  I went home and he told me there would be a nice surprise for me. I was looking through the windows and was thinking ‘Where is he ’. Then [his] work called and said he was late for a sht. I told them he’d be back soon. His phone was going to answerphone but I thought the battery had gone because he’d been out all day. Belaid had taken Talia to Tunisia and, a day later, completed their journey to Libya. The girl has lived in the country wrecked by civil war ever since. Her dad ed in  and was arrested at Heathrow airport on suspicion of child abduction – but Talia remained in Libya.

title: women reduced tears after hotel
story: NewsWomen reduced to tears after hotel upgrades them to house down the roadChristine Noddings and Shirley-Anne Gray had both booked rooms at Central House, Cheltenham. but were told they had to stay in a house ten minutes down the roadShareCommentsBySamuel PortGrace Witherden:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsThe pair said they were told they were being upgraded to a terraced house "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo women, who spent almost £ for a night in Cheltenham, have slammed the hotel they were booked into after being upgraded to a terraced house. Christine Noddings and Shirley-Anne Gray had both booked rooms at Central House, Cheltenham, to attend the funeral of a friend. However the pair of -year-olds were both shocked when they were told on the night they arrived from Essex they had to go where.Upon arrival they were told the upgrade was a three-bedroom house just aposten minutes down the roadapos, reports Gloucestershire Live.   Mrs Noddings said: We went inside and found that it was not the kind of place we wanted to stay, particularly since it only had one bathroom. Ms Gray and Mrs Noddings have to have their own bathrooms for ious reasons. God knows what the rooms at the Central Hotel were likewe had been ‘upgraded’, added Ms Gray. After the pair complained they said they were sent to another address - which turned out to be a house with people in. Ms Gray added: At this point we felt that we had been conned - not a good feeling I can tell you at  o’clock at night.      Mrs Noddings said: By this time, we were crying.  It was very dark, very wet and we had been on the road a long time and just wanted to go to bed. We were tired, we were worried and we were fed up. They ed to Central Hotel to demand their actual rooms, a refund and an explanation.    The hotel staff admitted to getting the address wrong. The women were reportedly told again that they had received an aposupgradeapos and that there was nothing that could be done. So, the pair set off again, now to another house in Gloucester Road. When they finally got to the accommodation it was pm, a full two hours after arriving at the hotel and six-and-a-half hours after setting off from home. The two women discovered that the apartment was up three flights of stairs and that they would have to heave all their luggage up there.    The next day, the exhausted women were late to the funeral by  minutes. The two women had worked together with their late friend  years ago in admin, so this was an emotional time for them, they said Central Hotel were dismissive of the womenaposs complaints by email, said the pair.  A manager emailed them: I am sorry to hear you were unhappy with your upgrade however we had upgraded you as a good will gesture and the reason behind this is because usually when we upgrade our guests we have outstanding reviews because of this. Unfortunately in these circumstances, I would like to apologise that you were unsatisfied with your upgrade. The manager added thatthe women had rung the -hour help line their query would have been answered and they would have found the correct address. Their request of a refund was refused. Booking initially offered the pair £ in compensation but later changed its stance. Mrs Noddings said: The £ was an insult to be honest.

title: what really landed roswell weirdest
story: NewsWhat really landed in Roswell as weirdest conspiracy theories are exposedOn July   years ago something strange happened in Roswell - but no one has the facts as to whatShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  JUL NewsDid aliens really land at Roswell "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn July , , mysterious object crashed out of the sky at Roswell, New Mexico. The next day the small townaposs local paper reported that a Flying Saucer had been captured by the Roswell Army Airfield and one of the worldaposs most enduring conspiracy theories was born. The rumour that an alien craft had crash landed in Roswell even seemed to be backed up by the authorities. The official Air Force press release reported that a flying disc had been recovered. And ever since, the most famous aposalienapos landing has captured the imaginations of conspiacy theorists across the globe.  Despite the US military insisting the object was nothing more than a normal weather balloon that had crash landed, the rumours wouldnapost die down. The Roswell incident has inspired a countless stream of films, TV shows, blogs, fake videos and theories. And the US government did very little to pour water on these theories until the late s. Only then did the military publish two reports containing the apostruthapos about what landed at Roswell. It was a nuclear test surveillance balloon from Project Mogul, a top secret operation to detect sound waves from Soviet atomic bomb tests. But there are many who donapost believe the official explanation and claim what really landed at Roswell on July   years ago was much more sinister.  Alien autopsy Almost  years after the incident a video of a supposed alien autopsy emerged. The grainy black and white footage seemed to show an extraterrestrial being. The film was released by London-based businessman, Ray Santilli, who claimed it had been given to him by a retired military cameraman. It was a bombshell and spawned countless documentaries and theories. However,  years later Santilli admitted the whole thing had been a fake. UFOs and Hitler It has been claimed that the object was in fact part of a project to test Nazi flying machine technology. People who believe this theory say a craft called The Bell, which was propelled with electric particles was being taken out for test flights at the site.  It has been claimed the technology behind the air craft had been the peak of Hitleraposs plans for world domination and it was still so sensitive it had to be kept secret - even today. German engineer, George Klein, said: I donapost consider myself a crackpot or eccentric or someone given to fantasties. This is what I saw with my own eyes - a Nazi UFO. Nuclear cover up The first mainstream conspiracy book to be published about the events at Roswell hit the shelves in . The Roswell Incident claimed an alien aircraft had been flying over the desert, observing US nuclear weapons activity. But while it was carrying out this covert mission, it was hit by lightning and crashed, killed the unknown creatures on board. Authors Charles Berlitz and William Moore insisted they had interviewed more than  witnesses and the event had remained secret because of a government cover up.  Two crash sites and aliens in custody The book Crash At Corona claims there was not one crash at Roswell but two - with a second flying saucer also hitting the earth. Authors Stanton Friedman and Don Berliner also claimed in the book that two aliens had been found alive and were now in the custody of the US government. Corporate aliens One of the wilder claims, which has been largely discredited, claims the materials pulled from the crash site were given to private industryu. Written by US Army Colonel Philip J Corso, the book claimed he had been conscripted into a top secret government programme involved in retrieving the debris from the crash. Corso also claimed the world was at war with alients but that earth was winning the battle.  Underground alien battle Witnesses have even come forward to claim that there was a huge battle between US special forces and extraterrestrials. Theorists say the aliens had set up a massive underground camp and that as many as  troops and locals were killed in the huge firefighter. Civil engineer Phil Schneider made the claims after he says he was himself confronted by the Alien Greys and managed to shoot two of them to death. Egg-shaped aircraft Retired Special Agent Richard Doty has not only claimed alients DID land at Roswell but also claims he knows exactly what was found. In the Netflix documentary Unacknowledge, Richard says the craft the ETaposs landed in was egg-shaped and that aliens were found inside. He said they were around feet tall and, while several were badly injured, there were survivors.

title: arthur rides 1000 miles from perth to germany in memory of tragic tayside girl harlow
story: His bike is nowhere near as quick as the super sporty cars he looks after in Tayside as workshop controller at Porsche.But Arthur Booth nevertheless chose to use two wheels instead of four to ride the , miles from the Perth Porsche premises, which is part of the Peter Vardy Group, to the German company’s HQ in Stuttgart to raise money for a very worthy cause.The -year-old has raised nearly £, for the Harlow’s Helping Hand fund which has been set up in memory of Coupar Angus toddler Harlow Edwards who died after being knocked down by a car in the town in October .The fund helps bereaved parents who have lost young children by providing support for funeral and headstone costs.Arthur said: “It took me nine days to get there.“I set off from Perth to Whitley Bay on the north-east coast of England then went down to York and King’s Lynn. From there I caught a ferry from Harwich to Rotterdam and made my way to Stuttgart via Den Bosch and Venlo, which are also in Holland, and on to Koblenz, Mainz and Mannheim in Germany before ending up in Stuttgart.“Once there, I saw round the Stuttgart factory and museum before coming home by train.”Arthur decided to undertake his gruelling journey for Harlow’s Helping Hand as a former colleague had been helped by the fund.He added: “Along the way people asked me why I was cycling such a distance so I told them about Harlow and they kindly donated money. Raising money for charity is one of the things my company does as a way of giving something back to the community.“This isn’t the first long distance bike ride I have completed.“I have previously cycled from Land’s End to John O’Groats with the money I raised going to a charity in Edinburgh named The Yard which raises cash for adventure playgrounds for disabled children.”

title: benjamin siegrist looking to make history as he aims for top flight place
story: Benjamin Siegrist was flattered to be linked with a move to the English Championship over the summer.But other than to the Premiership with Dundee United, the Swiss goalkeeper isn’t planning of going anywhere for quite some time.Siegrist’s performances in the second half of last season, culminating in a string of five-star displays during the promotion play-offs, saw him watched by Nottingham Forest.That was nice to hear as he enjoyed a few weeks off last month but, as he focuses on the coming season with the Tangerines, fans will be delighted to learn it’s not turned his head.“It was nice but it just proved the point to me I know what I can do and I know where the standards lie,” he said.“I am more than happy here. I know what I have here and I work well with the staff.“I know how big a club this is and I am really happy to be here.“And what is important for me is I want to be one of those players who go in the history books of this club and say he was one who got promotion for the team.“I want to improve and learn every week. As a team I think we got better last season as the games continued and I think I got better as a goalkeeper.“We want to keep doing that this year and,we do, we will get back to where we want to be.“Everybody knows where this club belongs and everybody wants to be part of achieving that ultimate goal of getting promoted.“That’s a big point of incentive and motivation for all the players.”Siegrist admits a bonus for him as he ed to work last week was teaming up again in training with fellow-goalie Deniz Mehmet.He was at United until January and has ed with a view to signing up again.“We crossed paths before when we were younger, at international tournaments with Switzerland and Turkey.“Coming from clubs down south we also faced each other. We are competing for the same place but there is always the goalkeepers’ union that means we stick together and it is nice to be working every day with someone you like.”Very much one for looking forward, Siegrist refuses to dwell too long on the disappointing end to last term that saw United again miss out on promotion in the play-offs.And when he does look back, he takes the positives.“I think what happened last year is part of our motivation for this year but I don’t want to speak too much about it because we start from zero again for a new season.“You do every year. In terms of experience it is good that we have had big games, big occasions together and that will help us.“It is like money in the bank but this season is about doing it consistently and picking up points over the whole of the year.”Tonight sees the start of a busy weekend when the entire squad will be involved in a friendly at Brechin before heading for Dumbarton tomorrow to do it all again.Two games in less than  hours may seem unusual but, for Siegrist, it will be the perfect way to prepare for the start of the competitive action in the Betfred Cup at Hearts next week.“So far as fitness goes we are good and game time is the most valuable time you have as a player,” he added.“You can train all week butyou don’t have a game at the end of it you are not bringing everything you’ve worked on together.“It is good to have as many games as we can so we are looking forward to these two games.“There is a lot more to football than passing and running, so game time is the most valuable part of pre-season.”

story: A north-east aquarium is to play host to two events to celebrate one of Scotland’s most iconic fish.Macduff Marine Aquarium is to host two events this year as part of the International Year of Salmon.The first, a Super Salmon fun day, will be held at the centre on Wednesday. Preview@PJ Live will also be asked to help test out the new arena – from flushing toilets to taking part in a full evacuation of the building – in preparation for opening later this summer.The free, ticketed preview on Saturday August  will not only showcase the state-of-the-art complex, but also provide entertainment from local musicians, offer a chance to sample the best local food and drink produce, plus provide activities for the kids.Nick Waight, managing director at PJ Live said it was “great” to reach this next stage.He said: “We’re excited to give everyone a chance to come and have title: health
story: A circus performer who is gearing up to wow the crowds in Aberdeen has spoken of her battle with breast cancer.Circus Extreme will begin on July  at the Queen’s Links and will see a range of performers in the tent.One of those who will showcase her skills is Laura Miller, an aqua aerialist.The -year-old was diagnosed with breast cancer five years ago and feared it would mark the end of her career.However, after a nearly three-year fight, she is performing again and said the circus and audience helped her get through the ordeal.Laura said: “Giving up is not my thing, I just wanted to go back to the ring.“I have done my hardest exam.“Now I have to mediate, but it’s worth all the fighting.”Her act features her flying weightlessly through the air, before ing into a glass tank filled with water.She has been one of the stars of the ring since  and is fulfilling a lelong dream with her act. Laura, originally from Bognor Regis, has also set up a self-help group on Facebook for young women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer.She said: “Such offers are rare for people of my age, those affected need support.”As well as Laura’s flying water mermaid act, there will also be a range of other performers.These include the Danguir Troupe, who will be performing a highwire and double wheel of death stunt, the Extreme FMX team, which features pilots flying through the air displaying stunts and a further riding team who will take on the Globe of Death.On top of this, there will also be Henry the Prince of Clowns, a cloud swing, trapeze, juggling and a troupe of dancers, all of which promise to thrill circus-goers of all ages.Circus Extreme will be in Aberdeen from July  until .The show will run for approximately two hours, with a matinee and evening performance on most days.Tickets for the event cost between £ and £ for adults and £ to £ for children, students, over-s and jobseekers.They can be booked online via Ticketmaster or by calling the circus box office between am and pm each day on  .

title: new service aims to support aberdeens veterans
story: A new scheme to help veterans in Aberdeen is to be launched.Poppyscotland is behind a new service to boost the support available for the armed forces across the country, including Aberdeen.The welfare support service will be made up of four officers and two independent living advisers, each working within a designated geographical area.They will provide support to vulnerable veterans and those identied as having complex needs.Support will also be given to help give those with long-term health issues the ability to maintain their independence and live in their own homes for longer.Looking after Aberdeen is Laura Gavin, the welfare support officer for the Highlands, Islands, Moray and Grampian.Laura said: “Being in a position to offer welfare support to people who have served or are still serving gives me great pride in being able to help meet the needs of beneficiaries at a time in their lives which could be proving dficult for them.”Gary Gray, the head of welfare services at Poppyscotland, added: “We reach out to those who have served, those still serving and their families at times of crisis and need by offering vital, practical advice.”

title: revealed aberdeens favourite most visited oor wullie sculptures
story: A sculpture honouring one of the north-east’s greatest sporting heroes is proving to be one the most popular attraction in a charity art trail.Oor Wullie Miller, one of the statues created as part of Oor Wullie’s BIG Bucket Trail in support of children’s hospital charities around Scotland including the ARCHIE Foundation, has been voted the best in Aberdeen.The sculpture was created in recognition of Aberdeen FC hero Willie Miller, .Thousands of people using the accompanying smartphone app to track their progress have had their say, voting for their favourite sculptures as they go.The statue honouring the European Cup Winners’ Cup-winning Dons skipper, which was created by artist Sarah Mauchline, sits outside the Bon Accord shopping centre and is currently out in front with a total of  votes.Map: Here are the locations of all  Oor Wullie sculptures in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local map-here-are-the-locations-of-all--oor-wullie-sculptures-in-aberdeen-and-aberdeenshire embed # secretECzCuK" data-secret"ECzCuK" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Willie, who played  times for the Pittodrie side, said: “I am glad people are taking to the statue, but the most important thing is the charities do well.“I’ve seen quite a lot of the statues throughout Scotland and I think the job they are doing is the important thing.“I am delighted the people passing mine have taken to it. I’m especially pleased for the charities and for the artist Sarah who designed it.“I am really happy to take part in such a good cause which will hopefully raise a lot of money for some really deserving charities.”However, the Dons-themed statue is not the most-visited sculpture.That title has gone the way of the Brave Wee Boy piece, which is at Aberdeen Beach.It has been visited , times by those using the app.Meanwhile, Oor Wullie Miller has had , visits and Oor Roadie – which is near Marks and Spencer – has been visited , times.And We All Scream For Ice Cream, outside Marischal Square, has had , visits and Oor Cabbie – beside Union Square and the rail station – had ,.Jamie Smith, ARCHIE’s regional fundraising manager, said: “The statistics are incredible. Oor Wullie’s BIG Bucket Trail is all about bringing communities together to enjoy art and the great outdoors, while raising awareness and vital funds for Scotland’s children’s hospital charities.”Sculptures on the Aberdeen trail have been visited , times since it was officially launched and a total of , rewards have been collected on the app.Across Scotland, the statues have been visited , times by those using the app.Jamie added: “We look forward to seeing even more people out and about this summer and would encourage anyone who wants to fundraise during the trail – maybe a sponsored walk or cycle around some of the statues – to email hello@archie.org.”Around  sculptures have been installed around Scotland’s five main cities – Aberdeen, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Dundee and Inverness.Map: Where you can find the wee Oor Wullie sculptures around Aberdeen" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local map-where-you-can-find-the-wee-oor-wullie-sculptures-around-aberdeen embed # secretwyeULjCtm" data-secret"wyeULjCtm" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"A further  smaller versions decorated by schoolchildren in the north-east have been placed in libraries in Aberdeen as part of the trail’s education programme, encouraging youngsters to be creative.The sculptures will be auctioned off when the trail ends in September.

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowWild and wet weather on opening night did not stop beer and music lovers from attending this year#s Fyne Fest.The muddy Cairndow field seemed to add to the fun as children jumped in puddles.It was only one rainy night and soon the sun was out to greet the acts as they took to the stages with wellies hitting the dance floor.More than  acts entertained beer-lovers over the weekend. On Friday, the Dice Ceilidh Band warmed up the drenched crowd with feverish dancing to traditional music, before Massaoke got everyone singing at a karaoke session with a -piece band playing the classics.Saturday#s headliners Bombskare, #the undisputed masters of Scottish reggae#, delivered a bouncing, infectious dance sound for their latest trip to FyneFest. Preceding them was The Camans with a slew of classic covers to get everyone moving and across the field in the Brewers Lounge, Brian McColm delivered acoustic indie rock classics to a chilled tent of beer-enthusiasts.Sunday saw revellers recovering and the tunes become more relaxing. These ranged from the soulful country-tinged songs of Liam Somerville to the harp-infused blues from Avocet and Lochgilphead#s Bar None Choir.Fyne Ales managing director Jamie Delap said: #Despite everything the weather threw at us, we had a great weekend. Paintings, drawing, sculptures, prints and collages were all featured exploring themes of astrology, politics, nature, history and the human body.Clare McCartan#s silver stainless steel leaf was the first thing to catch your eye by the door. title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

title: improving attitudes to health
story: Barabel McKayUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsLast year we were studying the Argyll and Bute Health and Social Care Partnership#Transforming Together#   document, which presented a vision of combining our will and skills to create a healthy future for the citizens of Argyll.The promises in that did not translate into reality.Now, a  beautully constructed and presented Living Well document is available. It runs to  pages, and must have taken signicant time and money to produce.It relies heavily on community participation and the Third Sector Interface .While it was being prepared the HSCP was in the process of getting rid of volunteer forums, TSI was shedding staff and Guided Self Help was being transferred to the NHS Mental Health Team, while essential services are still dependent on successful bids for money.Planning must not be a substitute for provision. In Living Well we are told that hypertension is by far the most common long-term condition. This area lacks the yearly health checks which might lead to early detection and intervention.The initiative and enthusiasm of hospital staff in improving mobility have already been commended, but the dearth of professional rehabilitation services in the community is nothing short of a disgrace.Everyone  seems to recognise this # indeed at a recent housing conference the keynote speaker highlighted the need for intervention to halt the downward slide into dependency. In an English trust they have even  appointed a physiotherapist to identy reversible causes of frailty.We have to fight complacency about our own health and in the attitudes of our health care providers.To contact Mid Argyll Health and Care Forum, email the forum chairperson Barabel McKay at barabelmck@gmail

title: racing buzz returns to famous kilmartin circuit
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThere was a palpable air of excitement in the air as racing ed to Kilmartin.The course, in the shadow of Carnasserie Castle and newly reclaimed from a dense layer of bracken, lived up to its reputation as a true championship test.The course # home to the only ever Scottish round of the GP World Motocross Championship in June  # played host to round five of the  Scottish Twin Shock championship in the first race to have been held there in decades.The track itself is  natural undulating land and not a man-made track, described by racing aficionados as a place for #vintage scrambling motocross#.Hot and dry weather in the week leading up to the event on Saturday June  was interrupted by a shower on race morning and this, combined with cut vegetation on the track, made for interesting conditions early in proceedings # which simply added to the excitement.Ricky Caldwell, chairman of the Scottish Twin Shock Scramble Club, said: #The sighting laps caused a little bit of a hold at the bottom of the hills due to the rain which had fallen which made a couple of the hills very slippery at the start of the day.#A few riders had not realised this and had a little sit down on them to gather their thoughts and then have another go. Once we got the racing underway everything flowed along very well indeed and there was some fantastic racing for all to watch.#He added: #Everyone connected with the club had an absolute awesome weekend at Kilmartin, and the place was buzzing.#It was especially great to see such a large number of spectators who made the effort to come along to watch, and after speaking to a few of them they seemed to have enjoyed themselves as much as we did .#Special mention and thanks must go to Jonathan McLeod who was the driving force behind this event, and without his enthusiasm and effort this would not have happened.#We also need to thank the three unsung local workers Ronnie, Jamie and Johnny ,who along with Jonathan all put a tremendous amount of work into the track over the last couple of weeks, cutting down all the bracken by hand on the hill areas, cutting grass and all round general work to ensure this race meet went ahead.#Ricky Caldwell concluded: #The riders are excited about coming back next year # so watch this space.#

title: bannerfield-besties-goes-to-print
story: BUDDING authors from a summer camp in Selkirk have finally gone to print.With a little help from a few parents, the schoolchildren wrote and illustrated Bannerfield Besties.And going by the reception it got at a launch last week, the coming-of-age page-turner is well worth a read.Parent Camilla Anderson told us: ldquoThe summer programme really brought the local community together with the children, along with parents carers, all having had a fantastic time creating the story."We are all grateful to the organisers for putting together such a brilliant programme and look forward to what is going to be happening this year."Bannerfield Besties recounts the adventures of three special friends who have fun and play together in the local area.When two of them find themselves in a pickle, help comes from a very unexpected source.And the moral of the story, that we all have some talents and skills that can sometimes help other people, resonates with readers.Last weeks launch at Philiphaugh Community Centre was attended by the authors, parent helpers and dozens of guests.Parent Ky Pettie was impressed with the finished book.She said: ldquoIt was good fun doing the drawings of the lion and the cheetah and it is wonderful to see how well they turned out now that the story has been published.The summer programme runs every Thursday throughout the school holidays at the Philiphaugh Community Centre.The programme, which is free for all accompanied children, includes fun, fitness and crafts activities as well as breakfast and lunch.Councillor Carol Hamilton, executive member for Children and Young People, is impressed with Bannerfield Besties.She said: ldquoThis is a delightfully original story that the contributing authors and artists should be extremely proud of."It must be so rewarding for them to see the results of their hard work in printed form and I would encourage anyone who gets the chance to read the story and perhaps learn something from the message it contains.ldquoI have no doubt the activities programme that will be running at Philiphaugh this summer will be equally creative and enjoyable and now is the ideal time for everyone to get in touch and book their place.A copy of Bannerfield Bestie is available to read at Selkirk Library and also the towns health centre.

title: broughtons-community-store-welcomes-first-customers
story: BROUGHTONS community shop has finally opened for business.Since the Village Store closed  months ago, locals have been forced into -mile round trips for essentials.But following a major community effort, the premises were bought, refitted and finally stocked.Local MP David Mundell cut the ribbon at the store two weeks ago following the refurbishment.And the doors finally opened to customers on Saturday with a brisk trade being reported over the first few days.Christopher Lambton, chair of the Upper Tweed Community Enterprise group, told us: "There is still a little work to do - a sink to be plumbed in, hot pie and coffee machines to be installed, newspaper accounts to be transferred, and further stock to arrive, but it is already clear that this is a spacious, clean and well-stocked shop that is a pleasure to visit."Come and visit, buy something, andwe havent got what you want let our manager Jen know."Broughton Community Shop is open on week days between am and pm.And also between am and pm on Sundays.Mr Mundell has congratulated the Upper Tweed Community Enterprise group for leading the way with the purchase and opening.He said: "A village shop can be an important hub in rural le in many ways and Im delighted to see how well Upper Tweed Community Enterprise have carried this project forward so well."The opening hours and services offered by the new store will regularly be reviewed.

title: high-flyer-gala-pilot-tom-is-supporting-armed-forces-day
story: EX-RAF navigator Tom Nash from Galashiels swapped fast flying for fast fibre after leaving the forces and joining digital network business Openreach.Tom, , hung up his brevet and made the move into civilian le after a -year career in the RAF as a Tornado GR navigator.Following stints as a cycle mechanic and mountain bike coach, he joined around , ex-armed forces personnel now working at Openreach, where hersquos helped to build fibre networks in rural Scotland and works with the public sector on the rollout of fast broadband.Despite the busy day job, the dad-of-two continues to make good use of his flying experience ndash by volunteering for the Tweed Valley Mountain Rescue Team and being chief pilot for affiliated charity the Search  Rescue Aerial Association Scotland.Until this year, Tom was Scotlandrsquos sole Search  Rescue drone operator, but in the last few months hersquos trained a further five volunteers to operate drones for use in searches and rescues around Scotland.This week, hersquos been supporting armed forces charity SSAFA by holding a Big Brew Up cake-and-a-cuppa event for colleagues in the run-up to Armed Forces Day.The event raised more than pound on top of pound banked for the charity last year when he and four colleagues ran in the Scottish K in East Lothian.Tom, who clocked up . days in the air while serving in the RAF, said: ldquoI needed to leave the military because it became incompatible with the family le I wanted."We took a gamble and moved from just outside London back to the Borders where my we Lynnrsquos family lived.ldquoA friend whorsquod joined the RAF on the same day as me back in  had already made the move to Openreach, and suggested I apply to its Accelerated Leadership scheme.ldquoThere are lots of similarities between the military and Openreach. They are both large, disparate organisations where strong logistical and organisation skills are needed. Teamwork, problem-solving and good communication skills are also essential!ldquoPeople coming in from the forces bring fresh ideas to the business, and itrsquos great to work for a company that has a strong bond with the Armed Forces community. What I like most is that what we do affects peoplersquos lives in a positive way.ldquoOver the  years I was in the RAF, technology and connectivity got better and better. This made communication with families back in the UK possible in a way that didnrsquot happen before. Openreachrsquos part in that canrsquot be underestimated.Openreach employees can spend three working days a year volunteering for their chosen cause, but as a volunteer with the emergency services, Tom can take up to  working days with the support of his manager.When Tom was Scotlandrsquos sole drone pilot, he could be dispatched anywhere in Scotland. Training up more drone pilots means the Mountain Rescue service now has greater capacity to assist in rescues all over Scotland.Drones are increasingly used in searches for people missing in the mountains but the service is also looking at innovations, such as using them as communication hubs in areas where therersquos poor or no signals.Dave Wright, Team Leader at Tweed Valley Mountain Rescue, said: ldquoAs a volunteer service the Tweed Valley Mountain Rescue team are totally reliant on the support of both the iniduals who give up their time but also to companies like Openreach who support volunteering.ldquoWithout the dedication of our volunteers and the backing of their employers we would not be able to provide this vital emergency service in our community.Openreach is one of the UKrsquos biggest employers of veterans and reservists, with around , in total and more than , ex-service personnel recruited since .It has nearly  active reservists, around  of whom are also part of the British Armyrsquos  Signal Squadron.

title: wake-me-up-before-you-go-go-to-hawick
story: FANS of George Michael and Wham! are in for a treat next week.The George Michael Story is coming to Hawick Town Hall.With a live band and video screens supporting the show, including video footage of George and interviews with the man himself, The George Michael Story starts with George in the Wham! days in the early s and moves onto the Grammy Award-winning Faith - Michaels debut solo album.The latter part of the show features Georgersquos more mature hits, and touches on some of his emotional and heartfelt songs.And the night culminates in a finale that is guaranteed to surprise the audience and have them singing along.George sold over  million records worldwide, making him one of the best-selling music artists of all time.He had seven number one hits in the UK Singles Chart and eight number ones on the US Billboard Hot .He was well-known for his philanthropy, and in his memory,  percent of ticket sale profits and  percent of merchandise sale profits from this show will be donated to his favourite charities: ChildLine, Terrence Higgins Trust, Comic Relief, Rainbow Trust Childrenrsquos Charity, Macmillan Cancer Support, Cardiomyopathy UK and Project Angel Food.Scott Weir, area manager at Live Borders, said: "Wersquore really looking forward to seeing The George Michael Story performed in the Borders."The live music is incredible, so we know it will be a fun night and it definitely fits with Live Bordersrsquo aim to help make communities happier."Hawick Town Hall is a great venue and we are excited about the erse programme of events coming to us this year."I would recommend looking on our website for more information.The George Michael Story is performed in Hawick on Friday, July .Doors open at pm.

title: selkirk-rideout-to-support-scotts-tiny-changes
story: SELKIRKS Ex Standard Bearers are set to saddle up to boost a mental health charity formed in memory of Frightened Rabbit singer Scott Hutchison.The -year-old took his own le in  after struggling with mental health issues for many years.Scott left behind a musical legacy which continues to touch people around the world.And on the anniversary of his death in May, his brothers, Neil and Grant, and parents, Marion and Ron, launched the Tiny Changes charity in his memory.The remaining members of Frightened Rabbit released a tenth anniversary covers version of their seminal The Midnight Organ Fight album last month to benefit Tiny Changes.And now the town where Scott, Grant and fellow band member Billy Kennedy grew up is also backing the charity.All proceeds from the Ex Standard Bearers Associations charity ride on Saturday, August  will go to Tiny Changes.Scott Tomlinson, who is one of the organisers, told us: "Every year we discuss which charities we should support with the charity ride and when Tiny Changes was suggested everyone was in favour."Scott was a Selkirk boy and we want to remember him by supporting his charity."For the past six years, more than  riders have taken part in the Ex Standard Bearers charity ride.Thousands have been raised for local causes and organisations each year.Tiny Changes aims to raise awareness of children and young peoplersquos mental health issues, as well as advancing understandings of the root causes.The charity also wants to provide support and promote initiatives that help children impacted by mental health problems, along with their families and carers.All proceeds from the charity ride and the riders social evening which follows will benefit the charity.And a crowdfunding page has also been set up to compliment the event.Mr Tomlinson added: "We want to raise as much money as possible for this very worthwhile charity."Mental health is something that impacts so many people of all ages."The charity ride is a great challenge for riders and takes in some beautul scenery."Selkirk Standard Bearer Craig Monks will lead the -miles rideout along with Ex Standard Bearers James Cheyne, Stuart Coltherd and Mr Tomlinson.The cavalcade will take in the scenic Yarrow and Ettrick valleys as well as the rolling hills above Ashkirk.All riders will be asked to raise a minimum of pound sponsorship to take part.For further details about taking part contact Mr Tomlinson on  .

title: selkirk-high-to-log-on-first-in-ipad-rollout
story: PUPILS in Selkirk are set to be the first in the Borders to have classroom iPads.Scottish Borders Councils pound million Inspire Learning project has already started rolling out with teachers in all of the regions secondary schools being issued with the Apple devices.Following the summer holidays, Selkirk High pupils will all be issued with their own iPads.And they will be followed during the Autumn term by students at Kelso High, Hawick High and Earlston High.Teachers have been getting to grips with the new teaching methods throughout June.Selkirk art and design teacher Chris Dolan told us: ldquoI think this programme is going to see huge changes in teaching and learning - in the way I go about my lessons and plan for them as well as improving pupil engagement and even how pupils give me feedback on a piece of work theyrsquove been doing."I am really looking forward to the opportunity to start to use them in the classroom in the upcoming sessions.The iPad roll-out has come in for fierce criticism from parents and concerns continue over finances being taken from other school budgets to fund the devices.But many of the secondary school teachers who have undergone training sessions, have been impressed.Drama teacher Sam Swinton said: ldquoItrsquos something Irsquom really excited about."I think itrsquos going to open up a wealth of possibilities for our kids in terms of things like set design and performance evaluations."This is a great new chapter for drama in education.Pupils at Peebles High, Eyemouth High and Galashiels High will receive their iPads during the   winter term.And Berwickshire Highs devices will be delivered next year.Pupils in Jedburgh will be issued with iPads when their new school opens in the summer of .Peebles computing and business studies teacher Anne Delaney said: ldquoThe sessions have been really good."Inspire will make learning more accessible to all, with every pupil able to access materials both in the classroom and at home.The primary school roll-out will take place from next year.

title: council-told-school-library-pilot-not-been-a-good-experience
story: CONCERNS have been raised about the impact of removing librarians from school due to noise levels, disruption and children being left to police their own peers.Scottish Borders Council is currently running a pilot scheme at Galashiels, Peebles and Kelso high schools, which has seen pupils and volunteers replacing librarians.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Wednesday June , SNP councillor Andy Anderson, who represents Galashiels, told the chamber that the experience of pupils at Galashiels Academy has not been positive.He asked members of the ruling Tory Independent coalition: ldquoWe are about a year down the line in the pilot of librarian-less school libraries.ldquoWhat lessons have been learned from this from the schools taking part and how is this informing the future of our school libraries East Berwickshire councillor Carol Hamilton, who acts as the executiversquos member for children and young people, said: ldquoThe pilot in three high schools started in October . An interim evaluation took place in December  with minor changes being implemented in January  to address some minor issues.ldquoA more detailed evaluation was conducted in April  which provided useful feedback from students, staff and parents from all nine high schools.ldquoThe vast majority of respondents highlighted the importance of having access to a library for reading, digital, research and study.ldquoThe feedback has been analysed and options for realising the decision of previous council to identy savings is ongoing.ldquoIt will also be critical to ensure that future library provision needs to be equitable across the authority.To which councillor Anderson: ldquoFor Galashiels Academy this has not been a good experience. The school has reported to the parent council that the noise levels in the library has at times been disruptive to other library users and to nearby classes, and excessive litter has been left in the library.ldquoDespite a self-service system that is aimed to be straightforward to operate, books are not finding their way to their correct place in the library once they have been ed.ldquoS pupils have been tasked throughout the year to keep the library running, but they also have their own studies and other activities that they volunteer for.ldquoThe former library service provision has in effect been replaced with a service run by pupils with little or no training, who should not be left to police their peers.ldquoThe perception is that this is merely another cost-cutting exercise by Scottish Borders council with little or no obvious benefit to the pupils.ldquoThis experience has been similar in Eyemouth, in the memberrsquos own ward, and has been backed up by a detailed letter from the chair of Eyemouth Parent Council sent to her and other councillors.ldquoThis backs up the experiences at Galashiels Academy. Dare I say it, there appears to have been a lack of lsquoinspired learningrsquo in this process.ldquoSurely you must agree that it is time to abandon this ill-conceived pilot and get our school libraries back to being fully al centres for study and learning for the benefit of our pupils.In response, councillor Hamilton acknowledged that there are issues with the scheme at Galashiels Academy: ldquoLast night I went to Galashiels to watch their production of High School Musical and I did speak to the parent chair, and I am aware of the issues and we are addressing them.ldquoThere are still a report to come about the libraries and wersquore having to look at each library as each library is dferent in terms of its layout, and the building.ldquoSome schools are looking a dferent service from their schools sothere is anything further Irsquoll come back to you.

title: roads-firm-to-rewrite-signs-following-tourist-u-turns
story: CONTRACTORS behind a closed road near the Grey Mares Tail have been forced to rewrite their signs.Because of Openreach cabling being laid near Moffat, the A road to Selkirk is closed in both directions for  days.The daytime closures, between am and pm, started this week.And businesses in the Yarrow Valley have already reported a major downturn in trade.Although the closure on the Dumfries and Galloway side of the local authority boundary was expected to lead to a drop in visitors from the south-west, misleading signs from the other end of the road have hurt retailers and hoteliers further.Closure signs placed in Selkirk, Traquair, Innerleithen, Tweedsmuir and at other minor roads leading onto the A dont indicate where the road is closed.And, according to business owners in the valley, many tourists are performing u-turns rather than making their ways up to the scenic St Marys Loch.On Monday morning, the Glen Cafe next to St Marys Loch had only served a handful of customers.At the nearby Gordon Arms staff were also twiddling their thumbs.Susan Cree from the Gordon Arms told us: "I went into Selkirk to see what the signs said and during the time I stopped there were two camper vans pulling up at the sign and about to turn around."They only continued up the valley after I told them where the road was closed."Weve already had cancellations from people who were intending travelling from the Moffat side, and we are a lot quieter today than we would normally be."We appreciate that things have to get done but this is our busiest time of the year - this -day closure is in the middle of the holiday season."Pre-warning signs about the closure led to businesses in the valley alerting Dumfries and Galloway to the misleading wording.And they were promised that changes would be made ahead of the closures.Susan added: "We wanted to lessen the impact as much as we could and the council said they would have the signage changed, but that hasnt happened."The sign at the crossroads outside the Gordon Arms is telling drivers not to go any further, yet there are businesses at St Marys Loch and the road isnt closed until beyond Grey Mares Tail."The A will be closed at Camp Cottage until next Wednesday at the earliest.Following complaints about the signs, Dumfries and Galloway held an emergency meeting with contractors.And they have promised that new signs will be erected.A spokesman for the local authority said: "A meeting has taken place with the contractor for the works on the A."Following this meeting, new signage is being placed on the route by the contractor as a matter of urgency."The new signage will reflect the time that the closure is in place and the exact location of the closure."

title: poppyscotland-welfare-service-marches-into-the-borders
story: POPPYSCOTLAND has launched a new service to transform the support available for the Armed Forces community in Scotland.And the Scottish Borders is one of the areas where the new, enhanced service will be available.The Welfare Support Service is open to the Armed Forces community across the country, but, crucially, it will have a strong local focus and will be tailored to the needs of each inidual.Looking after the Borders area is Welfare Support Officer Fiona Deacon.Fiona, who served for almost  years in the Royal Military Police and became the first woman to cast Colours during Selkirk Common Riding, told us: ldquoAs an Armed Forces veteran myself, I feel very privileged to be part of this new community-based beneficiary-focused service."I look forward to working in partnership with other service providers and charitable organisations to achieve the best possible results for our Armed Forces veterans and their families.The Welfare Support Service team will be made up of four Welfare Support Officers and two Independent Living Advisers, each working within a designated geographical area.The Welfare Support Officer will provide support to vulnerable veterans and to those identied as having complex needs.These could range from mental or physical health to problems with money and housing.As well as acting as the personal point of contact for Poppyscotlandrsquos clients, members of the new team will work alongside a wide network of agencies, professionals and volunteers to ensure that veterans in the Borders who require support get the help needed.Independent Living Adviser Mary Spence covers Glasgow, Lanarkshire, Forth Valley, Ayrshire, Dunbartonshire, Renfrewshire  Inverclyde, Argyle  Bute, Renfrewshire  Inverclyde, Dumfries  Galloway and the Scottish Borders.She said: ldquoI am delighted to be joining Poppyscotland in my capacity as an Independent Living Adviser, working alongside our partners to deliver person-centred services to our beneficiaries and their families.ldquoIn this, the th year since D-Day, it has never been more important or relevant to remember the sacrices made every day by our Armed Forces and, as importantly, their families, and the debt we owe them. We are already busy with referrals and have been able to provide advice, support and financial assistance to the Armed Forces Community across Scotland.To find out more information about Poppyscotlandrsquos new Welfare Support Service visit www.poppyscotland.org.uk get-help .
